verses.textLa: Et petiit dum introiret, ut daretur ei copia nocte et ante lucem egrediendi foras ad orationem, et deprecandi Dominum.

verses.textEn: And he instructed his chamberlains that she may exit and enter, just as it may please her, to adore her God, for three days.
verses.textLa: Et præcepit cubiculariis suis ut sicut placeret illi, exiret et introiret ad adorandum Deum suum, per triduum:

verses.textEn: And she went out in the nights into the valley of Bethulia, and she washed herself in a fountain of water.
verses.textLa: et exibat noctibus in vallem Bethuliæ, et baptizabat se in fonte aquæ.

verses.textEn: And, as she climbed up, she prayed to the Lord God of Israel that he would direct her way, to the liberation of his people.
verses.textLa: Et ut ascendebat, orabat Dominum Deum Israel, ut dirigeret viam eius ad liberationem populi sui.

verses.textEn: And entering, she remained pure in the tabernacle, until she received her own food in the evening.
verses.textLa: Et introiens, munda manebat in tabernaculo usque dum acciperet escam suam in vespere.

verses.textEn: And it happened on the fourth day that Holofernes made a supper for his servants, and he said to Vagao his eunuch: “Go, and persuade that Hebrew woman to willingly consent to live with me.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, in quarto die Holofernes fecit cœnam servis suis, et dixit ad Vagao eunuchum suum: Vade, et suade Hebræam illam ut sponte consentiat habitare mecum.

verses.textEn: For it is disgraceful among the Assyrians, if a woman mocks a man, acting so as to pass through with immunity from him.”
verses.textLa: Fœdum est enim apud Assyrios, si femina irrideat virum agendo ut immunis ab eo transeat.

verses.textEn: Then Vagao entered toward Judith, and he said, “May she not dread, my good young woman, to enter to my lord, so that she may be honored before his face, so that she may eat with him and drink wine with cheerfulness.”
verses.textLa: Tunc introivit Vagao ad Iudith, et dixit: Non vereatur bona puella introire ad dominum meum, ut honorificetur ante faciem eius, ut manducet cum eo, et bibat vinum in iucunditate.

verses.textEn: Judith answered him: “Who am I, that I should contradict my lord?
verses.textLa: Cui Iudith respondit: Quæ ego sum, ut contradicam domino meo?

verses.textEn: All that will be good and best before his eyes, I will do. Moreover, whatever will please him, to me, that will be what is best, all the days of my life.”
verses.textLa: Omne quod erit ante oculos eius bonum et optimum faciam. Quidquid autem illi placuerit, hoc mihi erit optimum omnibus diebus vitæ meæ.

verses.textEn: And she arose and dressed herself with her garments, and entering, she stood before his face.
verses.textLa: Et surrexit, et ornavit se vestimento suo, et ingressa stetit ante faciem eius.

verses.textEn: But the heart of Holofernes was struck. For he was burning with desire for her.
verses.textLa: Cor autem Holofernes concussum est: erat enim ardens in concupiscentia eius.

verses.textEn: And Holofernes said to her, “Drink now, and recline with cheerfulness, for you have found favor before me.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad eam Holofernes: Bibe nunc, et accumbe in iucunditate, quoniam invenisti gratiam coram me.

verses.textEn: And Judith said, “I will drink, my lord, because my soul has been magnified this day, beyond all my days.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit Iudith: Bibam domine, quoniam magnificata est anima mea hodie præ omnibus diebus meis.

verses.textEn: And she accepted and ate and drank in his sight what her handmaid had prepared for her.
verses.textLa: Et accepit, et manducavit, et bibit coram ipso ea, quæ paraverat illi ancilla eius.

verses.textEn: And Holofernes became pleased with her, and he drank very much wine, more than he had ever drunk in his life.
verses.textLa: Et iucundus factus est Holofernes ad eam, bibitque vinum multum nimis, quantum numquam biberat in vita sua.

verses.textEn: So then, when it had become late, his servants hurried to their lodgings, and Vagao closed the chamber doors, and he went away.
verses.textLa: Ut autem sero factum est, festinaverunt servi illius ad hospitia sua, et conclusit Vagao ostia cubiculi, et abiit.

verses.textEn: But they were all drowsy from the wine.
verses.textLa: Erant autem omnes fatigati a vino:

verses.textEn: And Judith was alone in the chamber.
verses.textLa: eratque Iudith sola in cubiculo.

verses.textEn: Moreover, Holofernes, being very inebriated, was fast asleep, reclining on his bed.
verses.textLa: Porro Holofernes iacebat in lecto, nimia ebrietate sopitus.
verses.notes: The word ‘sopitus’ does not indicate normal sleep, but rather sleep due to some external force, such as alcohol, or a soporific remedy (ancient version of sleeping pills), or a blow to the head.

verses.textEn: And Judith told her handmaid to stand outside before the chamber, and to watch.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Iudith puellæ suæ ut staret foris ante cubiculum, et observaret.

verses.textEn: And Judith stood in front of the bed, praying with tears, and her lips moved in silence,
verses.textLa: Stetitque Iudith ante lectum, orans cum lacrymis, et labiorum motu in silentio,

verses.textEn: saying: “Confirm me, O Lord God of Israel, and in this hour look kindly upon the works of my hands, so that, just as you promised, you may raise up Jerusalem, your city, and so that, believing through you that this plan is able to be accomplished, I may succeed.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Confirma me Domine Deus Israel, et respice in hac hora ad opera manuum mearum, ut, sicut promisisti, Ierusalem civitatem tuam erigas: et hoc quod credens per te posse fieri cogitavit, perficiam.
verses.notes: Notice that this phrase is translated somewhat more loosely ‘et hoc quod credens per te posse fieri cogitavit,’ so that the verb ‘cogitavit’ is even translated as a noun ‘plan,’ rather than ‘what was planned.’ In translation, sometime the better rendering changes the tense of the verb, or the case of a noun, or even, in this unusual case, changes a verb into a noun.

verses.textEn: And when she had said this, she approached the pillar, which was at the head of the bed, and she released his blade, which was hanging tied to it.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc dixisset, accessit ad columnam, quæ erat ad caput lectuli eius, et pugionem eius, qui in ea ligatus pendebat, exolvit.

verses.textEn: And when she had unsheathed it, she grabbed him by the hair of his head, and she said, “Confirm me, O Lord God, in this hour.”
verses.textLa: Cumque evaginasset illum, apprehendit comam capitis eius, et ait: Confirma me Domine Deus in hac hora.

verses.textEn: And she struck him twice on his neck, and she cut off his head, and she took off his canopy from the pillars, and she rolled away the trunk of his body.
verses.textLa: Et percussit bis in cervicem eius, et abscidit caput eius, et abstulit conopœum eius a columnis, et evolvit corpus eius truncum.

verses.textEn: And after a little while, she went out, and she delivered the head of Holofernes to her handmaid, and she ordered her to put it in her bag.
verses.textLa: Et post pusillum exivit, et tradidit caput Holofernis ancillæ suæ, et iussit ut mitteret illud in peram suam.

verses.textEn: And the two went out, according to their custom, as if to prayer, and they passed through the camp, and having circled around the valley, they came to the gate of the city.
verses.textLa: Et exierunt duæ, secundum consuetudinem suam, quasi ad orationem, et transierunt castra, et gyrantes vallem, venerunt ad portam civitatis.

verses.textEn: And Judith, from a distance, spoke to the watchmen on the walls, “Open the gates, for God is with us, and he has acted with his power in Israel.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit Iudith a longe custodibus murorum: Aperite portas, quoniam nobiscum est Deus, qui fecit virtutem in Israel.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when the men had heard her voice, they called the elders of the city.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, cum audissent viri vocem eius, vocaverunt presbyteros civitatis.

verses.textEn: And all rushed toward her, from the least to the greatest. For, until then, they held no hope that she would return.
verses.textLa: Et concurrerunt ad eam omnes, a minimo usque ad maximum: quoniam sperabant eam iam non esse venturam.

verses.textEn: And, enflaming the lights, they gathered all around her. But she climbed up to a higher place, and she ordered them to be made silent. And when all had quieted down,
verses.textLa: Et accendentes luminaria congyraverunt circa eam universi: illa autem ascendens in eminentiorem locum, iussit fieri silentium. Cumque omnes tacuissent,

verses.textEn: Judith said: “Praise the Lord our God, who has not abandoned those who hope in him.
verses.textLa: dixit Iudith: Laudate Dominum Deum nostrum, qui non deseruit sperantes in se:

verses.textEn: And by me, his handmaid, he has fulfilled his mercy, which he promised to the house of Israel. And he has killed the enemy of his people, by my hand this night.”
verses.textLa: et in me ancilla sua adimplevit misericordiam suam, quam promisit domui Israel: et interfecit in manu mea hostem populi sui hac nocte.

verses.textEn: Then, taking the head of Holofernes from the bag, she displayed it to them, saying: “Behold, the head of Holofernes the leader of the military of the Assyrians, and behold his canopy, under which he reclined in his drunkenness, where the Lord our God struck him by the hand of a woman.
verses.textLa: Et proferens de pera caput Holofernis, ostendit illis, dicens: Ecce caput Holofernis principis militiæ Assyriorum, et ecce conopœum illius, in quo recumbebat in ebrietate sua, ubi per manum feminæ percussit illum Dominus Deus noster.

verses.textEn: But, as the Lord himself lives, his angel has been my guardian both from my departure, and while staying there, and when returning from there. And the Lord has not permitted me, his handmaid, to be defiled, but he has called me back to you without the pollution of sin, rejoicing in his victory, in my escape, and in your liberation.
verses.textLa: Vivit autem ipse Dominus, quoniam custodivit me Angelus eius et hinc euntem, et ibi commorantem, et inde huc revertentem, et non permisit me Dominus ancillam suam coinquinari, sed sine pollutione peccati revocavit me vobis gaudentem in victoria sua, in evasione mea, et in liberatione vestra.

verses.textEn: Confess everything to him, for he is good, for his mercy is with every generation.”
verses.textLa: Confitemini illi omnes, quoniam bonus, quoniam in sæculum misericordia eius.

verses.textEn: Then everyone adored the Lord, and they said to her, “The Lord has blessed you by his power, because, through you, he has reduced our enemies to nothing.”
verses.textLa: Universi autem adorantes Dominum, dixerunt ad eam: Benedixit te Dominus in virtute sua, quia per te ad nihilum redegit inimicos nostros.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, Uzziah, the leader of the people of Israel, said to her: “O daughter, you have been blessed by the Lord, the most high God, above all the women on earth.
verses.textLa: Porro Ozias princeps populi Israel, dixit ad eam: Benedicta es tu filia a Domino Deo excelso præ omnibus mulieribus super terram.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord, who made heaven and earth, who has guided you in harming the head of the leader of our enemies.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus, qui creavit cælum et terram, qui te direxit in vulnera capitis principis inimicorum nostrorum:

verses.textEn: For he has so magnified your name this day, that your praise will not retire from the mouth of men, who will be mindful of the power of the Lord forever, because you have risked your life for the sake of the distress and tribulation of your people, and you have prevented our ruin before the sight of our God.”
verses.textLa: quia hodie nomen tuum ita magnificavit, ut non recedat laus tua de ore hominum, qui memores fuerint virtutis Domini in æternum, pro quibus non pepercisti animæ tuæ propter angustias et tribulationem generis tui, sed subvenisti ruinæ ante conspectum Dei nostri.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘non peperisti’ literally means ‘you have not spared,’ but this is more succinctly expressed as ‘you have risked....’

verses.textEn: And all the people said: “Amen. Amen.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit omnis populus: Fiat, fiat.

verses.textEn: And so, Achior was called, and he drew near, and Judith said to him: “The God of Israel, to whom you gave testimony, has avenged himself on his enemies. He has cut down the head of all unbelievers, by my hand this night.
verses.textLa: Porro Achior vocatus venit, et dixit ei Iudith: Deus Israel, cui tu testimonium dedisti quod ulciscatur se de inimicis suis, ipse caput omnium incredulorum incidit hac nocte in manu mea.

verses.textEn: And, so that you may determine that this is so, behold, the head of Holofernes, who, in the contempt of his pride, despised the God of Israel and threatened Israel with ruin, saying, ‘When the people of Israel have been captured, I will instruct your sides to be pierced through with a sword.’ ”
verses.textLa: Et ut probes quia ita est, ecce caput Holofernis, qui in contemptu superbiæ suæ Deum Israel contempsit, et tibi interitum minabatur, dicens: Cum captus fuerit populus Israel, gladio perforari præcipiam latera tua.

verses.textEn: Then Achior, seeing the head of Holofernes, and being distressed by fear, fell upon his face on the ground, and his soul became agitated.
verses.textLa: Videns autem Achior caput Holofernis, angustiatus præ pavore, cecidit in faciem suam super terram, et æstuavit anima eius.

verses.textEn: In truth, after this, when he had recovered his breath, he fell down before her feet, and he showed reverence for her, and he said:
verses.textLa: Postea vero quam resumpto spiritu recreatus est, procidit ad pedes eius, et adoravit eam, et dixit:

verses.textEn: “Blessed are you by your God, in every tabernacle of Jacob, for in every nation that will hear of your name, the God of Israel will be magnified over you.”
verses.textLa: Benedicta tu a Deo tuo in omni tabernaculo Iacob, quoniam in omni gente, quæ audierit nomen tuum, magnificabitur super te Deus Israel.

verses.textEn: Then Judith said to all the people: “Hear me, brothers. Suspend this head over our walls.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Iudith ad omnem populum: Audite me fratres, suspendite caput hoc super muros nostros:

verses.textEn: And, as soon as the sun rises, let everyone take up his weapons and go out to attack, not going down all the way, but only to seem as if making an assault.
verses.textLa: Et erit, cum exierit Sol, accipiat unusquisque arma sua, et exite cum impetu, non ut descendatis deorsum, sed quasi impetum facientes.

verses.textEn: Then the scouts will have to hurry to awaken their leader for the fight.
verses.textLa: Tunc exploratores necesse erit ut fugiant ad principem suum excitandum ad pugnam.

verses.textEn: And when their commanders rush into the tabernacle of Holofernes, and they find his headless body wallowing in his blood, fear will fall over them.
verses.textLa: Cumque duces eorum cucurrerint ad tabernaculum Holofernis, et invenerint eum truncum in suo sanguine volutatum, decidet super eos timor.

verses.textEn: And when you realize that they are fleeing, go after them in security, for the Lord will crush them under your feet.”
verses.textLa: Cumque cognoveritis fugere eos, ite post illos securi, quoniam Dominus conteret eos sub pedibus vestris.

verses.textEn: Then Achior, seeing the power that the God of Israel had wrought, left behind the rituals of the Gentiles. He believed in God, and he circumcised the flesh of his foreskin, and he was placed among the people of Israel, and so were all the succession of his kindred, even until this present day.
verses.textLa: Tunc Achior videns virtutem, quam fecit Deus Israel, relicto gentilitatis ritu, credidit Deo, et circumcidit carnem præputii sui, et appositus est ad populum Israel, et omnis successio generis eius usque in hodiernum diem.

verses.textEn: And soon, at the rising of day, they suspended the head of Holofernes above the walls, and every man took up his weapons, and they went out with a great uproar and howling.
verses.textLa: Mox autem ut ortus est dies, suspenderunt super muros caput Holofernis, accepitque unusquisque vir arma sua, et egressi sunt cum grandi strepitu et ululatu.

verses.textEn: When the scouts saw this, they rushed to the tent of Holofernes.
verses.textLa: Quod videntes exploratores, ad tabernaculum Holofernis cucurrerunt.

verses.textEn: Moreover, those who were in the tent came and made a loud noise before the entrance to the bedchamber, hoping to awaken him by an attempt at skillful noise-making, not by intruding on him, so that Holofernes might be roused from sleep.
verses.textLa: Porro hi, qui in tabernaculo erant, venientes, et ante ingressum cubiculi perstrepentes, excitandi gratia, inquietudinem arte moliebantur, ut non ab excitantibus, sed a sonantibus Holofernes evigilaret.

verses.textEn: For no one dared to knock, or to open and enter, the bedchamber of the powerful leader of the Assyrians.
verses.textLa: Nullus enim audebat cubiculum virtutis Assyriorum pulsando aut intrando aperire.

verses.textEn: But when his commanders and tribunes had arrived, with all the chiefs of the army of the king of the Assyrians, they said to the chamberlains:
verses.textLa: Sed cum venissent eius duces ac tribuni, et universi maiores exercitus regis Assyriorum, dixerunt cubiculariis:

verses.textEn: “Enter and awaken him, for the mice have come out of their holes, intending to challenge us to fight.”
verses.textLa: Intrate, et excitate illum, quoniam egressi mures de cavernis suis, ausi sunt provocare nos ad prælium.

verses.textEn: Then Vagao, entering his bedchamber, stood before the curtain, and he made a clapping noise with his hands. For he suspected that he was sleeping with Judith.
verses.textLa: Tunc ingressus Vagao cubiculum eius, stetit ante cortinam, et plausum fecit manibus suis: suspicabatur enim illum cum Iudith dormire.

verses.textEn: But when, with attentiveness, he perceived no motion of anyone reclining, he approached the curtain. And lifting it up, he saw the dead body of Holofernes, without a head, lying on the ground, soaked in his own blood. He cried out with a loud voice and weeping, and he tore his garments.
verses.textLa: Sed cum nullum motum iacentis sensu aurium caperet, accessit proximans ad cortinam, et elevans eam, vidensque cadaver absque capite Holofernis in suo sanguine tabefactum iacere super terram, exclamavit voce magna cum fletu, et scidit vestimenta sua.

verses.textEn: And he entered the tent of Judith and did not find her. And he ran out to the people,
verses.textLa: Et ingressus tabernaculum Iudith, non invenit eam, et exiliit foras ad populum,

verses.textEn: and he said: “One Hebrew woman has caused confusion in the house of Nebuchadnezzar the king. For behold, Holofernes lies on the ground, and his head is not with him.”
verses.textLa: et dixit: Una mulier Hebræa fecit confusionem in domo regis Nabuchodonosor: ecce enim Holofernes iacet in terra, et caput eius non est in illo.

verses.textEn: Now when the leaders of the army of the Assyrians had heard this, they all tore their garments, and an intolerable fear and trembling fell over them, and their minds were greatly disturbed.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audissent principes virtutis Assyriorum, sciderunt omnes vestimenta sua, et intolerabilis timor et tremor cecidit super eos, et turbati sunt animi eorum valde.

verses.textEn: And there was an unprecedented outcry in the midst of their camp.
verses.textLa: Et factus est clamor incomparabilis in medio castrorum eorum.
verses.notes: The outcry was ‘incomparable’ or ‘unprecedented.’

verses.textEn: And when the entire army had heard that Holofernes was beheaded, reason and resolution fled from them, and, being moved by trembling and fear alone, they thought only to flee to safety.
verses.textLa: Cumque omnis exercitus decollatum Holofernem audisset, fugit mens et consilium ab eis, et solo tremore et metu agitati, fugæ præsidium sumunt,

verses.textEn: So then, no one spoke with his neighbor, but hanging their heads and leaving everything behind, they hurried to escape from the Hebrews, who, as they had heard, were advancing against them well-armed. And they fled through the ways of the fields and the paths of the hills.
verses.textLa: ita ut nullus loqueretur cum proximo suo, sed inclinato capite, relictis omnibus, evadere festinabant Hebræos, quos armatos super se venire audiebant, fugientes per vias camporum et semitas collium.

verses.textEn: And so, the sons of Israel, seeing them fleeing, pursued them. And they went down after them, sounding the trumpets and howling.
verses.textLa: Videntes itaque filii Israel fugientes, secuti sunt illos. Descenderuntque clangentes tubis, et ululantes post ipsos.

verses.textEn: And, since the Assyrians were not united, they rushed headlong in their flight. But the sons of Israel, pursuing like one unit, struck down all they were able to find.
verses.textLa: Et quoniam Assyrii non adunati, in fugam ibant præcipites: filii autem Israel uno agmine persequentes, debilitabant omnes, quos invenire potuissent.

verses.textEn: And so, Uzziah sent messengers through all the cities and regions of Israel.
verses.textLa: Misit itaque Ozias nuncios per omnes civitates et regiones Israel.

verses.textEn: And then, every region and every city sent their chosen young men with weapons after them, and they pursued them with the edge of the sword, until they passed through to the extremities of their borders.
verses.textLa: Omnis itaque regio, omnisque urbs electam iuventutem armatam misit post eos, et persecuti sunt eos in ore gladii, quousque pervenirent ad extremitatem finium suorum.

verses.textEn: But the remainder, who were in Bethulia, entered the camp of the Assyrians and took away the plunder that the Assyrians, in their flight, had left behind, and they were exceedingly burdened.
verses.textLa: Reliqui autem, qui erant in Bethulia, ingressi sunt castra Assyriorum, et prædam, quam fugientes Assyrii reliquerant, abstulerunt, et onustati sunt valde.

verses.textEn: In truth, those who returned victorious to Bethulia brought with them everything that was theirs. So there was no numbering their cattle, and beasts, and everything they could carry, so much so that, from the least to the greatest, all were made rich by their spoils.
verses.textLa: Hi vero, qui victores reversi sunt ad Bethuliam, omnia quæ erant illorum attulerunt secum, ita ut non esset numerus in pecoribus, et iumentis, et universis mobilibus eorum, ut a minimo usque ad maximum omnes divites fierent de prædationibus eorum.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘universis mobilibus eorum’ could also be translated as ‘all their movables’ or ‘all their transportable items.’

verses.textEn: But Joachim, the high priest, came from Jerusalem to Bethulia with all his elders to see Judith.
verses.textLa: Ioacim autem summus pontifex de Ierusalem venit in Bethuliam cum universis presbyteris suis ut videret Iudith.

verses.textEn: And when she had gone out to him, they all blessed her with one voice, saying: “You are the glory of Jerusalem, you are the joy of Israel, you are the honor of our people.
verses.textLa: Quæ cum exisset ad illum, benedixerunt eam omnes una voce, dicentes: Tu gloria Ierusalem, tu lætitia Israel, tu honorificentia populi nostri:

verses.textEn: For you have acted manfully, and your heart has been strengthened. For you loved chastity, and, after your husband, you have not known any other. Therefore, also the hand of the Lord has strengthened you, and, therefore, you will be blessed for all eternity.”
verses.textLa: quia fecisti viriliter, et confortatum est cor tuum, eo quod castitatem amaveris, et post virum tuum, alterum nescieris: ideo et manus Domini confortavit te, et ideo eris benedicta in æternum.
verses.notes: The praise given to Judith in the Scriptures is really praise for the Virgin Mary. For Judith is a mere foreshadowing of Mary. It may seem as if Judith is praised excessively, but the full meaning is praise for the Mother of God.

verses.textEn: And all the people said: “Amen. Amen.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit omnis populus: Fiat, fiat.

verses.textEn: But all of thirty days were scarcely enough for the people of Israel to collect the spoils of the Assyrians.
verses.textLa: Per dies autem triginta, vix collecta sunt spolia Assyriorum a populo Israel.

verses.textEn: But moreover, all of those things that were clearly the particular possessions of Holofernes they gave to Judith: with gold, and silver, and garments, and gems, and furniture. And these were all delivered to her by the people.
verses.textLa: Porro autem universa, quæ Holofernis peculiaria fuisse probata sunt, dederunt Iudith in auro, et argento, et vestibus, et gemmis, et omni supellectili, et tradita sunt omnia illi a populo.

verses.textEn: And all the people rejoiced, with the women, and the virgins, and the young men, playing on wind instruments and stringed instruments.
verses.textLa: Et omnes populi gaudebant cum mulieribus, et virginibus, et iuvenibus, in organis, et citharis.

verses.textEn: Then Judith sang this canticle to the Lord, saying:
verses.textLa: Tunc cantavit canticum hoc Domino Iudith, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Call to the Lord with drums, sing to the Lord with cymbals, play for him a new psalm, exalt and invoke his name.
verses.textLa: Incipite Domino in tympanis, cantate Domino in cymbalis, modulamini illi psalmum novum, exaltate, et invocate nomen eius.

verses.textEn: The Lord crushes wars; the Lord is his name.
verses.textLa: Dominus conterens bella, Dominus nomen est illi.

verses.textEn: He has set up his camp in the midst of his people, to rescue us from the hand of all our enemies.
verses.textLa: Qui posuit castra sua in medio populi sui, ut eriperet nos de manu omnium inimicorum nostrorum.

verses.textEn: Assur came from the mountains, from the North, with the multitude of his strength. His multitude blockaded the torrents, and their horses covered the valleys.
verses.textLa: Venit Assur ex montibus ab Aquilone in multitudine fortitudinis suæ: cuius multitudo obturavit torrentes, et equi eorum cooperuerunt valles.
verses.notes: The name Assur refers to a false god of the Assyrians. As such, it is also used by Scripture to refer to the Antichrist, who will be a false god from the area of the world formerly held by the Assyrians. He will hide the fact that he is from the Middle East (the kingdom of the South) and he will become the king of the North (Europe). He comes to the kingdom of the South with a vast army and their vehicles (‘horses’) and he blockades the sources of water and the passages for travel.

verses.textEn: He told himself that he would set fire to my borders, and kill my young men with the sword, to give my children into plunder and my virgins into captivity.
verses.textLa: Dixit se incensurum fines meos, et iuvenes meos occisurum gladio, infantes meos dare in prædam, et virgines in captivitatem.
verses.notes: Even thought the word ‘infantes’ is the source of the English word ‘infant,’ it has a broader meaning in Latin. It can refer to infants, but, in other contexts, it refers more generally to children.

verses.textEn: But the almighty Lord has harmed him, and he has delivered him into the hands of a woman, and he has pierced him through.
verses.textLa: Dominus autem omnipotens nocuit eum, et tradidit eum in manus feminæ, et confodit eum.
verses.notes:
This verse gives credit to Judith, as the one to whom the enemy was handed over by God. However, the one who ‘confodit eum’ (runs him through), is the same one who ‘tradidit’ (same ending, same sentence construction), i.e. the Lord.
 The Book of Judith is actually about the Virgin Mary. Christ the Lord defeats the Antichrist, but he does so by means of the Virgin Mary. It is actually the Lord who defeats him, or runs him through, but the Virgin Mary – devotion to her, prayers of her Rosary, etc., and her ultimate return with Christ at the end of the Antichrist’s reign – are the means by which he is defeated.

verses.textEn: For their powerful one did not fall by young men, nor did the sons of Titan strike him, nor did lofty giants set themselves against him, but Judith, the daughter of Merari, dissolved him with the splendor of her face.
verses.textLa: Non enim cecidit potens eorum a iuvenibus, nec filii Titan percusserunt eum, nec excelsi gigantes opposuerunt se illi, sed Iudith filia Merari in specie faciei suæ dissolvit eum.

verses.textEn: For she put away from herself the garments of widowhood, and she clothed herself with the garments of rejoicing, for the sake of the exultation of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Exuit enim se vestimento viduitatis, et induit se vestimento lætitiæ in exultatione filiorum Israel.

verses.textEn: She anointed her face with ointment, and she gathered the locks of her hair with a headdress; she accepted a new dress in order to deceive him.
verses.textLa: Unxit faciem suam unguento, et colligavit cincinnos suos mitra, accepit stolam novem ad decipiendum illum.

verses.textEn: Her sandals ravished his eyes; her beauty made his soul her captive; with a blade, she cut off his head.
verses.textLa: Sandalia eius rapuerunt oculos eius, pulchritudo eius captivam fecit animam eius, amputavit pugione cervicem eius.

verses.textEn: The Persians were horrified at her constancy, and the Medes at her boldness.
verses.textLa: Horruerunt Persæ constantiam eius, et Medi audaciam eius.

verses.textEn: Then the camp of the Assyrians howled, when my humble ones appeared, parched with thirst.
verses.textLa: Tunc ululaverunt castra Assyriorum, quando apparuerunt humiles mei, arescentes in siti.

verses.textEn: The sons of the servant girls have pierced them through, and, like fleeing servants, they have killed them. They perished in battle before the face of the Lord, my God.
verses.textLa: Filii puellarum compunxerunt eos, et sicut pueros fugientes occiderunt eos: perierunt in prælio a facie Domini Dei mei.

verses.textEn: Let us sing a canticle to the Lord; let us sing a new hymn to our God.
verses.textLa: Hymnum cantemus Domino, hymnum novum cantemus Deo nostro.

verses.textEn: O Adonai, O Lord, you are great, and splendor is in your virtue, and no one is able to overcome you.
verses.textLa: Adonai Domine magnus es tu, et præclarus in virtute tua, et quem superare nemo potest.

verses.textEn: Let all your creatures serve you. For you spoke, and they became. You sent forth your Spirit, and they were created. And there is no one who can withstand your voice.
verses.textLa: Tibi serviat omnis creatura tua: quia dixisti, et facta sunt: misisti Spiritum tuum, et creata sunt, et non est qui resistat voci tuæ.

verses.textEn: The mountains will be moved from the foundations by the waters. The rocks, like wax, will liquefy before your face.
verses.textLa: Montes a fundamentis movebuntur cum aquis: petræ, sicut cera, liquescent ante faciem tuam.

verses.textEn: But those who fear you will be great with you, throughout all things.
verses.textLa: Qui autem timent te, magni erunt apud te per omnia.

verses.textEn: Woe to the people that rises up against my people. For the Lord almighty will be vindicated against them; in the day of judgment, he will visit them.
verses.textLa: Væ genti insurgenti super genus meum: Dominus enim omnipotens vindicabit in eis, in die iudicii visitabit illos.

verses.textEn: For he will bestow fire and worms on their flesh, so that they may burn and have sensations without ceasing.”
verses.textLa: Dabit enim ignem, et vermes in carnes eorum, ut urantur, et sentiant usque in sempiternum.
verses.notes: Here is a description of Hell, which clearly indicates that Hellfire includes physical torments of various kinds and that it is never-ending.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, after these things, all the people came to Jerusalem after the victory, to adore the Lord. And as soon as they were purified, they all offered holocausts, and vows, and their promises.
verses.textLa: Et factum est post hæc, omnis populus post victoriam venit in Ierusalem adorare Dominum: et mox ut purificati sunt, obtulerunt omnes holocausta, et vota, et repromissiones suas.

verses.textEn: Moreover, Judith offered all the implements of war from Holofernes, which the people gave to her, and the canopy that she had taken away from his chamber, as an anathema unto oblivion.
verses.textLa: Porro Iudith universa vasa bellica Holofernis, quæ dedit illi populus, et conopœum, quod ipsa sustulerat de cubili ipsius, obtulit in anathema oblivionis.

verses.textEn: But the people were cheerful before the face of the sanctuary, and for three months the gladness of this victory was celebrated with Judith.
verses.textLa: Erat autem populus iucundus secundum faciem sanctorum, et per tres menses gaudium huius victoriæ celebratum est cum Iudith.

verses.textEn: And after those days, each one returned to his own house, and Judith became great in Bethulia, and she had great splendor in all the land of Israel.
verses.textLa: Post dies autem illos unusquisque rediit in domum suam, et Iudith magna facta est in Bethulia, et præclarior erat universæ terræ Israel.

verses.textEn: For chastity was one with her virtue, so that she did not know man all the days of her life, after the passing away of her husband, Manasseh.
verses.textLa: Erat enim virtuti castitas adiuncta, ita ut non cognosceret virum omnibus diebus vitæ suæ, ex quo defunctus est Manasses vir eius.

verses.textEn: And then, on feast days, she came forth with great glory.
verses.textLa: Erat autem diebus festis procedens cum magna gloria.

verses.textEn: But she remained in her husband’s house for one hundred and five years, and she set her handmaid free. And she passed away and was buried with her husband in Bethulia.
verses.textLa: Mansit autem in domo viri sui annos centum quinque, et dimisit abram suam liberam, et defuncta est ac sepulta cum viro suo in Bethulia.

verses.textEn: And all the people mourned her, for seven days.
verses.textLa: Luxitque illam omnis populus diebus septem.

verses.textEn: And, during all the time of her life, there was no one who disturbed Israel, nor for many years after her death.
verses.textLa: In omni autem spatio vitæ eius non fuit qui perturbaret Israel, et post mortem eius annis multis.

verses.textEn: Moreover, the day of the festivity of this victory was accepted by the Hebrews in the numbering of holy days, and it was religiously observed by the Jews, from that time, even to the present day.
verses.textLa: Dies autem victoriæ huius festivitatis, ab Hebræis in numero sanctorum dierum accipitur, et colitur a Iudæis ex illo tempore usque in præsentem diem.
